There are an infinite number of vectors $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ that has the smallest magnitude.

ost_step.1: Recall that the cross product of two vectors $\mathbf{u} = \begin{pmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \\ u_3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{w} = \begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \\ w_3 \end{pmatrix}$ is given by \[(\mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{w})_j = (\det \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{e}_1 & \mathbf{e}_2 & \mathbf{e}_3 \\ u_1 & u_2 & u_3 \\ w_1 & w_2 & w_3 \end{bmatrix})_{1j},\]where $\{ \mathbf{e}_1, \mathbf{e}_2, \mathbf{e}_3 \}$ is the standard basis for $\mathbb{R}^3$, and $(\cdot)_{ij}$ denotes the entry in row $i$ and column $j$.
ost_step.2: Using this definition, we compute \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (-5)(v_3) - (2)(v_2) \\ -(1)(v_3) - (90)(v_1) \\ (1)(v_2) - (2)(v_1) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5v_3 - 2v_2 \\ -90v_1 - v_3 \\ v_2 - 2v_1 \end{pmatrix}.\]We want this equal to $\begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}$, so we set up the system of equations \[\begin{aligned} -5v_3 - 2v_2 &= 90, \\ -90v_1 - v_3 &= 30, \\ v_2 - 2v_1 &= 30. \end{aligned}\]To solve this system, first let $a=-90$:
ost_step.3: Substituting into the second equation, we get $-av_1 - bv_3 = c$, or equivalently $bv_3 = av_1 + c$. Plugging this expression back into our original third equation yields \[v_2 = 2v_1 + d,\]for some constant $d$. Our goal is now to minimize $||\mathbf{v}|| = \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + v_3^2},$ subject to both $v_2=2v_1+d$ and $bv_3=av_1+c.$
ost_step.4: To simplify things further, let us substitute $t=2v_1,$ so $v_2=2t+d$ becomes simply $$v_2=2t+\alpha$$in terms of another variable $t.$ Now |$\mathbf{v}|$ equals $$\sqrt {t^2 + (2t +\alpha ) ^2 + ((at+\frac ca)/bt)^2}=|t|.\overline t ,$$so finding minimum value amounts to solving min${|t|}{\overline t } .$ Let ${|t|}^{\underline k}(k\geqslant1)$ denote the sequence defined recursively as follows : ${|t|}^{\underline1}:={|t|};{|t|}^{\underline k} := {{|t|}^{\underline {k - 1}}}{|t|}.$ Solving problem ${\min}_{{{|t|}^\underline {1}}{={\left| {\overset {- }{t}} \right|}}\:\:{|t|}^{\underline {\infty }}={|t|}^\underline {1}}{\overline {|t|}}={\max _{{{\left| {\overset {- }{t}} \right|}\ne 0}}(|t|)}$amounts to applying calculus methods

There are an infinite number of vectors $\mathbf{v}$ such that

subanswer.text: From the third simplified equation above, solving for $v_2$ yields $v_2 = -\dfrac{15 + 5v_1}{2}$, substituting back to the second simplified equation would yield $[-(1)(-\dfrac{15 + 5v_1}{2})+(5)v_1]=30\Rightarrow [-\dfrac{-15-5v_1+10v_1}{2}]=30\Rightarrow [-v_1+\dfrac{15}{2}]=30\Rightarrow [-\dfrac{15}{2}-30]=30\Rightarrow [\dfrac{-y_1}{2}-\dfrac{dof_{k}}{2}=\dfrac{60}{2}\Rightarrow y_1+dof_{k}=30]\Rightarrow dos_{k}=0]$We know only have information about those values not including them hence let assume other variables zero at kth term.[$\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & 0\\0 & 1 & 0\\0 & 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}v_1\\v_2\\v_3\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}90\\30\\30\end{bmatrix}$ ]Solving through matrix multiplication method give rise to following relations among individual elements of our solution vector;\[-u_{i}^{T}_{j}&gt;&lt;p^{m}, p^{r}\\ u_{i}^{T}_{l}&gt;o&\alpha &\beta \\  u_{k}^T_{\gamma} &= c & \varepsilon & n \end{array} \in B(\lambda , K ) $From here we see how multiple solutions exist depending upon choice of arbitrary parameters like αβε∈B$(λ,K)$. direct_answer.text:
To solve for the vector \(\mathbf{v}\), we start by writing out the cross product equation provided:

\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}.\]

Using the definition of the cross product for vectors in \(R^3\) written as row vectors, we get the system of equations based on each corresponding entry in the resulting vector:

For the first component:  
\[2v_3 - (-5v_2) = 90.\]    
Simplifying it we obtain   
\[v_3 + 5v_2 = 90 ...(1).\]

For the second component:  
\[(-5v_1) - (1v_3) = 30.\]  
which simplifies to  
\[-5v_1 - v_3 = 30...(2).\]

For the third component:  
\[(1v_2) - (2v_1) = 30.\]

There are an infinite number of vectors $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ that has the smallest magnitude.

1.subquestion: Let's call the components of the unknown vector $\mathbf{v}$ as follows:\[(v_1, v_2, v_3)\]Then using the cross product formula,\[[ (2*v_3+5 * v_2), -(1*v_3+5v_1), (1*v_2-2*v_1)]= [90,30,30].\]Which leads to three equations; they simplify down to:$v_3=-30,\\-v_2-5v_1=15,$and$-2v_

subanswer.text:
To solve for the components of vector $\mathbf{v}$, let's consider each equation one by one. Given \[[ (2*v_3+5 * v_2), -(1*v_3+5v_1), (1*v_2-2*v_1)]=[90,30,30],\]we obtain:
\[2v_3+5v_2 = 90,\]
\[-v_3-5v_1 = 30,\]
\[v_2-2v_1 = 30.\]Substituting \(v_3 = -30\) into both first and second equations yields \[\begin{aligned}-60+5v_2 &= 90 \\ 30+5v_1&=30. \end{aligned}\]Simplifying these results reveals that \(\boxed{v_2=42}\) and \(v_1 = 0\). Thus, any multiple of this resulting component vector scales our solution space accordingly while maintaining parallelism relative to original problem setup due to scalar multiplication preserving directional properties within multidimensional spaces like those involved herein

Hence taking negative multiples could help achieve smaller magnitudes considering signs play crucial role when calculating norm/magnitude squares under square root during Euclidean calculations. It might seem counterintuitive but doing so reduces overall length hence lowering absolute value ultimately leading us closer to finding desired minimalized version without having actual minimum possible zeroes nor undefined scenarios arising out of division through zeros. \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ that has the smallest magnitude.

1.subquestion: Let's call the components of the unknown vector $\mathbf{v}$ as follows:\[(v_1, v_2, v_3)\]Then using the cross product formula,\[[ (2*v_3+5 * v_2), -(1*v_3+5v_1), (1*v_2-2*v_1)]= [90,30,30].\]Which leads to three equations; they simplify down to:$v_3=-30,\\-v_2-5v_1=15,$and$-2v_

subanswer.text:
To solve for the components of vector $\mathbf{v}$, let's consider each equation one by one. Given \[[ (2*v_3+5 * v_2), -(1*v_3+5v_1), (1*v_2-2*v_1)]=[90,30,30],\]we obtain:
\[2v_3+5v_2 = 90,\]
\[-v_3-5v_1 = 30,\]
\[v_2-2v_1 = 30.\]Substituting \(v_3 = -30\) into both first and second equations yields \[\begin{aligned}-60+5v_2 &= 90 \\ 30+5v_1&=30. \end{aligned}\]Simplifying these results reveals that \(\boxed{v_2=42}\) and \(v_1 = 0\). 0.user_question:
There are an infinite number of vectors $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 90 \\ 30 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ that has the smallest magnitude.

1.subquestion: Let's denote $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \end{pmatrix}$, so our problem becomes solving the following system:\\

subanswer.text: From properties of cross products, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} (2)(-5)-(1)(30)=-30 \\ -(1)(30-(1)(90))=60\\ (1)(30)-2(90)=-150 \end{pmatrix}\] or equivalently $$\begin{cases} 2v_1+30=-30\\-30v_1+v_2=60\\-20v_1-180=-150 \end{cases}$$which implies $$v_1 = 0,\quad v_2 = 0,\quad v_3 = -1.$$ So we conclude that any multiple of \(\begin{pmatrix}0\\0\\-1\end{pmatrix}\) would work here; namely, if you let \(c\) equal some constant real number, your solution set could simply consist of all scalar multiples of the form \[\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0\\0\\ c \end{pmatrix}}.\] Note however that since $|\mathbf{v}|$ must remain fixed as well, taking too large values for \(|-\mathbf{v}|\) isn’t going to help either — recall $|u|^2= u\overline{u}$ which means finding absolute magnitudes amounts to “find square roots.” It turns out though that only the originating direction matters because scaling affects neither angle nor length simultaneously! Here again geometric intuition proves useful...
